channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2026 The New York Times Company

item.title: On Eve of Peace Talks, Russia Hits Power Plants in Frigid Ukraine
item.description: Missiles overnight targeted electrical facilities in Kyiv and other parts of the country, according to local authorities, despite President Trump’s request for a pause.
item.dc:creator: Maria Varenikova
item.media:credit: Valentyn Ogirenko/Reuters
item.media:description: A resident and a police officer outside an apartment building hit by a Russian drone strike in Kyiv on Tuesday.

item.title: A Hamas Hostage’s Secret Ordeal
item.description: Guy Gilboa-Dalal says he was sexually abused by one of his captors in the tunnels of Gaza and threatened with death if he said anything.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: Guy Gilboa-Dalal near his parents’ home in Alfei Menashe, West Bank, in December. Mr. Gilboa-Dalal was abducted to Gaza from the Nova music festival on Oct. 7, 2023, and was released after more than two years in captivity.

item.title: After Maduro’s Capture, Venezuela’s Authoritarian System Shows Signs of Easing
item.description: A sweeping amnesty proposal, tests of censorship limits and opposition leaders emerging from hiding are fueling hopes for democratic changes. But skepticism abounds.
item.dc:creator: Simon Romero, Isayen Herrera and Patricia Sulbarán
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: The New York Times
item.media:description: El Helicoide, constructed as a shopping mall, holds dozens of Venezuela’s political prisoners.

item.title: Palestinians Return to Gaza for First Time in Nearly Two Years
item.description: Only 12 returnees were allowed to cross the newly reopened border with Egypt on the first day, far fewer than the expected number.
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon and Bilal Shbair
item.media:credit: Saher Alghorra for The New York Times
item.media:description: Palestinians embraced people who returned to Gaza late on Monday after the Rafah border crossing between Egypt and Gaza was reopened.

item.title: This is How Hard It Will Be to Get Around Italy’s Winter Olympics
item.description: The Games in northern Italy, which start on Friday, will be spread across 8,500 square miles. Long distances, narrow roads, complex connections and snowfall will make it a logistical nightmare.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz and Alessandro Grassani
item.media:description: During the opening ceremony for the Tai di Cadore bypass on State Road 51.

item.title: Son of Norway’s Crown Princess Goes on Trial Over Charges Including Rape
item.description: The trial of Marius Borg Hoiby, who has also been accused of assault and other crimes, began as his mother came under pressure over her ties to Jeffrey Epstein.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.media:credit: Hakon Mosvold Larsen/NTB, via Agence France-Presse – Getty Images
item.media:description: Marius Borg Hoiby in 2022. The 29-year-old has no title or official duties, but the charges against him have contributed to a sense of crisis for Norway’s royal family.

item.title: Police Search X’s Premises in France as Prosecutors Summon Elon Musk
item.description: The move followed a yearlong investigation into X and escalated a wider standoff between European officials and American tech companies over the regulation of social media.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter and Ségolène Le Stradic
item.media:credit: Markus Schreiber/Associated Press
item.media:description: Elon Musk in Davos, Switzerland, in January.

item.title: U.K. Investigates Peter Mandelson Over Jeffrey Epstein Ties
item.description: Peter Mandelson, a prominent British political figure, faces allegations of “misconduct in public office offenses” over his dealings with Jeffrey Epstein.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle and Lizzie Dearden
item.media:credit: Jaimi Joy/Reuters
item.media:description: Peter Mandelson last year.

item.title: Greenland Crisis Has Danes Chuckling, in Their Own Way
item.description: A little teasing has helped Danes manage their anger and anxiety over American threats to take a part of their territory. A Trump pincushion, anyone?
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: Hilary Swift for The New York Times
item.media:description: A hat reading “Nu det Nuuk!,” which roughly translates to “enough is enough,” in English, at a store in Copenhagen. The phrase “Make America Go Away” is on the side.

item.title: Trump and India Call Off Their Trade War, but the Terms of Peace Are Murky
item.description: Officials and business leaders welcomed lower tariffs, but India has not yet confirmed that it would stop buying Russian oil, which President Trump said Prime Minister Narendra Modi had agreed to.
item.dc:creator: Alex Travelli
item.media:credit: Eric Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India visited the White House last February, before bilateral relations between the countries decayed.

item.title: Paris Court Deals Family Blow in Battle for Rent From the French Embassy in Iraq
item.description: The court said it was not the right authority to handle the lawsuit for unpaid rent, and the case should be heard in Iraq, where the family’s ancestors had fled persecution.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni and Pranav Baskar
item.media:credit: Provided by the Lawee and Khazzam families
item.media:description: The French Embassy in Baghdad is in a house built in the 1930s.

item.title: Spain Aims to Ban Social Media for Children Under 16
item.description: The announcement is part of a broader push by countries to curb access to online platforms for minors. It also points to Europe’s stricter approach to regulating social media.
item.dc:creator: José Bautista
item.media:credit: Emilio Morenatti/Associated Press
item.media:description: A child playing on a phone in Barcelona in 2024. Prime Minister Pedro Sánchez of Spain said the social media ban would be part of a series of measures pushed by his government.

item.title: Iran’s President Backs ‘Fair’ Talks With U.S. as Confrontation Looms
item.description: President Masoud Pezeshkian said on Tuesday that he supported “equitable negotiations.” Talks are expected on Friday, as diplomats work to defuse the crisis.
item.dc:creator: Sanam Mahoozi
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: A billboard in Tehran last month depicted strikes on an American aircraft carrier.

item.title: How 2026 Winter Olympics Security Is Preparing For The Opening Ceremony
item.description: Thousands of police and security officers will work during the Milan-Cortina Games’ opening ceremony. The involvement of some U.S. ICE personnel has stirred opposition.
item.dc:creator: Tariq Panja
item.media:credit: Maja Hitij/Getty Images
item.media:description: Italian carabinieri in Milan on Sunday. The city is hosting the Winter Olympics this month.

item.title: South Korea Questions Cram School Culture and Childhood Stress
item.description: Academic pressure has become so intense that even preschoolers are taking private extracurricular classes, raising worries about children’s rights.
item.dc:creator: Max Kim and Jean Chung
item.media:description: Seoul has “Therapy Zone” boxes, soundproof spaces where students can study, or vent, in the evenings after school.

item.title: ‘Neoroyalism’ and What It Says About Trump
item.description: Experts are reaching to divine the president’s approach to global policy and economics, with one theory seeing antecedents in centuries-old dynastic rule.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Cohen
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman gave President Trump a warm and opulent welcome in Saudi Arabia last year.

item.title: Seif al-Islam el-Qaddafi, Son of Libyan Dictator, Is Killed
item.description: Mr. el-Qaddafi, 53, a politician and a son of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, was killed after four men stormed his house, the lawyer said. No other details were released.
item.dc:creator: Islam Al-Atrash and Ephrat Livni
item.media:credit: Moises Saman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Seif al-Islam el-Qaddafi gave an interview to The New York Times in Tripoli, Libya, in 2011.

item.title: All About the Epstein Files
item.description: Everyone seems to have questions about the sprawling scandal, so we talked to a reporter who’s been following the case for years.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold
item.media:credit: Jon Elswick/Associated Press

item.title: U.S. Fighter Jet Shoots Down Iranian Drone Amid Heightened Tensions
item.description: A U.S. fighter jet shot down the Iranian drone after it “unnecessarily maneuvered” toward the Abraham Lincoln aircraft carrier.
item.dc:creator: Greg Jaffe
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Fazry Ismail
item.media:description: F/A-18 fighter jets parked on the flight deck of the aircraft carrier Abraham Lincoln in 2024.

item.title: Ruptures in China’s Leadership Could Be Due to Paranoia and Power Plays
item.description: U.S. intelligence analysts say that Xi Jinping, China’s leader, has a remarkable level of fear. He has carried out mass purges, and surprised many by removing his top general.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong and Julian E. Barnes
item.media:credit: Greg Baker/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Xi Jinping during a military parade in Tiananmen Square in Beijing last year.

item.title: At Least 30 Dead After Weeks of Heavy Snowfall in Japan
item.description: Snowfall in parts of Japan has also left about 200 people injured. One city recorded 72 inches of snow, the highest in almost 40 years.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai and Kiuko Notoya
item.media:credit: Mizuki Sakai/Kyodo News, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The Tottori Sand Dunes in Tottori, Japan, last month.

item.title: Nepal Arrests 6 Officials, Accusing Them of Fraudulent Everest Rescues
item.description: The officials from mountain rescue agencies are accused of carrying out unnecessary helicopter rescues to defraud international insurance companies of nearly $20 million.
item.dc:creator: Binod Ghimire and Jenny Gross
item.media:credit: Prakash Mathema/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A helicopter flying over the Khumbu glacier near Mount Everest. The authorities in Nepal said rescue agencies carried out hundreds of fraudulent rescues.

item.title: ‘Biblical Diseases’ Could Resurge in Africa, Health Officials Fear
item.description: Parasites and infections that cause blindness and other disabilities were nearly eliminated in some countries, but drug distribution to prevent and treat them was derailed in many places in 2025 after the U.S. cut aid.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Nolen and Arlette Bashizi
item.category: United States Agency for International Development
item.media:credit: Arlette Bashizi for The New York Times

item.title: What to Know About the Disappearance of Savannah Guthrie’s Mom, Nancy
item.description: Nancy Guthrie, 84, the “Today” show host’s mother, was last seen on Saturday night, the authorities said. The disappearance is being investigated as a crime.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:credit: Sejal Govindarao/Associated Press
item.media:description: Law enforcement officers outside the home of Nancy Guthrie near Tucson, Ariz., on Monday.

item.title: What Do You Get When You Put a Mummy Through a CT Scan?
item.description: Experts are using high-res scanners and 3-D printers to illuminate ancient ailments and injuries.
item.dc:creator: Emily Baumgaertner Nunn
item.media:credit: Mark Abramson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Summer Decker and her colleague Jonathan Ford used a 3-D printer to generate replicas of body parts and artifacts.

item.title: Behind the ‘Free Maduro’ Message Spreading in Caracas
item.description: Our reporter Anatoly Kurmanaev looks around Caracas, Venezuela, describing how the “Free Maduro” graffiti and billboards around the city, which also appear on Delcy Rodríguez’s social media pages, help her as she balances her ties to Nicolás Maduro with her political rebranding.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev, Melanie Bencosme, Leila Medina and Stephanie Swart

item.title: The Campaign Behind Trump’s Nigeria Strikes
item.description: A yearslong effort to convince the Trump administration that Christians are persecuted in the West African nation has shifted U.S. policy.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Taibat Ajiboye for The New York Times
item.media:description: A resident of Jabo, Nigeria, with debris he said he found after a missile attack on Dec. 25 there.

item.title: U.S. and Iranian Officials to Meet as Trump’s Threats Loom
item.description: President Trump’s Middle East envoy and his son-in-law were expected to meet Iran’s foreign minister in Istanbul on Friday amid tensions between the countries.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard and Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: A billboard in Tehran showing Iran’s supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, reads “We recognize the American president as a criminal.”

item.title: Trump Announces Initial Trade Deal With India, Cutting Tariffs to 18%
item.description: The agreement was short on details, but President Trump said India had promised to stop buying Russian oil and would buy more U.S. farm goods and other products.
item.dc:creator: Erica L. Green, Tony Romm and Ana Swanson
item.media:credit: Eric Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump and India’s prime minister, Narendra Modi, were spare on details in their announcements, and Mr. Modi did not mention whether his country would stop buying Russian oil, as Mr. Trump claimed.

item.title: France Adopts a Budget After Months of Turmoil
item.description: Prime Minister Sébastien Lecornu’s budget, subjected to judicial review, paves the way for relative political stability.
item.dc:creator: Ségolène Le Stradic
item.media:credit: Bertrand Guay/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Prime Minister Sébastien Lecornu of France, center in blue suit, at the National Assembly on Monday. The budget’s passage is expected to allow for a semblance of political stability after months of turmoil.

item.title: Attempt to Drill Through Thwaites Glacier Is Foiled
item.description: Scientists lost their instruments within Antarctica’s most dangerously unstable glacier, though not before getting a glimpse at the warming waters underneath.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Threading a cable through the Thwaites glacier in an attempt to place monitoring equipment.

item.title: Uproar Over Meloni’s Face Painted on an Angel in a Church in Rome
item.description: The recent restoration of a chapel came with a surprise: an angel depicted with the likeness of Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni of Italy. Cue the protests.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:credit: Vincenzo Livieri/Reuters
item.media:description: A restored angel fresco with a figure resembling Giorgia Meloni in the Basilica of San Lorenzo in Lucina, in Rome.

item.title: Royal Families of Norway and Britain Face Pressure Over Epstein Files
item.description: Newly released emails offer new details about ties between Jeffrey Epstein and Crown Princess Mette-Marit of Norway, as well as Sarah Ferguson, once the Duchess of York in Britain.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg and Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Odd Andersen/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Crown Princess Mette-Marit of Norway in 2024, at a Nobel Peace Prize ceremony in Oslo. She said in a statement on Monday that she regretted her contacts with Jeffrey Epstein.

item.title: Countries Have Long Tested Their Own Athletes for Doping. That Could Soon Change.
item.description: After Chinese swimmers won Olympic gold in 2021 despite having tested positive for a banned substance, the World Anti-Doping Agency is considering whether to have an independent body handle testing before major events.
item.dc:creator: Tariq Panja
item.media:credit: Lintao Zhang/Getty Images
item.media:description: Zhang Yufei, center, at the meet where she tested positive for a banned substance in January 2021. Months later, she won four medals, including two golds, at the Tokyo Olympics.

item.title: Erfan Soltani, Who Reportedly Faced Death Sentence in Iran, Is Freed
item.description: Mr. Soltani, 26, was arrested last month as Iran brutally repressed anti-government demonstrations.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden

item.title: Colombia’s President, an Outspoken Trump Critic, Heads to the White House
item.description: President Gustavo Petro of Colombia and President Trump have had a tense relationship that escalated into threats by Mr. Trump, before easing. Anything could happen at their Feb. 3 meeting.
item.dc:creator: Annie Correal and Max Bearak
item.media:credit: Nathalia Angarita for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Gustavo Petro of Colombia at the presidential palace in Bogotá, the capital, in January.

item.title: Rafah Crossing in Gaza Reopens, Another Step for Fragile Cease-Fire
item.description: Israel and Egypt had disagreed for months about how to resume operations at the Rafah border crossing, which has been largely closed since May 2024.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner and Bilal Shbair
item.media:credit: Saher Alghorra for The New York Times
item.media:description: A medical convoy carrying patients in Khan Younis, Gaza, heading for the Rafah crossing on Monday. The opening of the crossing is expected to expedite the exit of thousands of sick and wounded people waiting for treatment abroad.

item.title: How a Village in Italy Became a Slice of Caracas
item.description: Generations of migrants from a village on the coast of southern Italy found a better life in Venezuela. Many came back and turned their town into a mini-Caracas.
item.dc:creator: Fabiola Ferrero

item.title: Laura Fernández Wins Costa Rican Presidency
item.description: Laura Fernández’s victory was driven by a crisis in which Costa Rica’s reputation for peace has been tarred by record-breaking violence.
item.dc:creator: Emiliano Rodríguez Mega and David Bolaños
item.media:credit: Cesar Rodriguez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Laura Fernández, Costa Rica’s president-elect, celebrating her election victory alongside supporters on Sunday evening.

item.title: Oscar-Nominated Screenwriter Arrested in Iran for Criticizing Regime
item.description: Mehdi Mahmoudian, co-writer of “It Was Just an Accident,” was one of several people detained after signing a letter objecting to the crackdown on protests.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: The Yomiuri Shimbun, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Mehdi Mahmoudian, a political activist and screenwriter, during an interview in Tehran in 2021.

item.title: Why Targeting Iran Is Riskier Than Ousting Maduro
item.description: Iran’s ability to strike Israel and destabilize the wider Middle East makes it a far more dangerous adversary.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: A mural in Tehran on Tuesday.

item.title: The Secret Egyptian Air Base Powering Sudan’s Drone War
item.description: The covert base offers new evidence of how the Sudanese conflict is morphing into a theater for high-tech warfare, driven by foreign interests.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh, Malachy Browne, Eric Schmitt and Nick Cumming-Bruce
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Satellite images by Vantor. The New York Times

item.title: Russia Strikes Ukraine’s Energy Sector, Killing 12 Miners
item.description: The attack comes during a winter freeze and despite efforts by President Trump and others to get the two countries to negotiate a truce.
item.dc:creator: Kim Barker
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: A tent provided by the government to provide heat and electricity in Kyiv last month. Russia has devastated Ukraine’s power grid this winter, the coldest in more than a decade.

item.title: Starmer Urges Former Prince Andrew to Testify to Congress Over Epstein Ties
item.description: Mr. Mountbatten-Windsor was stripped of his royal titles in October by his brother King Charles III because of growing questions around his links to Mr. Epstein.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:credit: Kirsty Wigglesworth/Associated Press
item.media:description: Britain’s Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor, formerly known as Prince Andrew, at St. George’s Chapel, Windsor Castle, England, last year.

item.title: What to Know About the Rafah Border Crossing in Gaza
item.description: The only crossing that connects Gaza with Egypt has reopened. The move will allow residents to leave for medical care or return to homes and families in the territory.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Rafah border crossing between the Gaza Strip and Egypt in 2023.

item.title: Ukraine Peace Talks Delayed After Russia and U.S. Meet
item.description: It was unclear why the latest round of negotiations, which had been expected on Sunday, were postponed for several days.
item.dc:creator: Kim Barker
item.media:credit: Tyler Hicks/The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian artillery unit firing at Russian positions in the Donbas region of Ukraine in December.

item.title: Indonesia Lifts Ban on Grok After New Assurances From X Corp
item.description: Indonesia joined Malaysia and the Philippines in reversing its restrictions, weeks after it blocked the chatbot because it was used to generate sexually explicit images of real people.
item.dc:creator: Jin Yu Young
item.media:credit: Joe Raedle/Getty Images
item.media:description: In this photo illustration, the Grok Imagine web page, which produces A.I.-generated images and video, is displayed on a computer screen.

item.title: Right-Wing Populist Holds Commanding Lead Ahead of Costa Rica’s Election
item.description: President Rodrigo Chaves’s handpicked successor has vowed to extend his agenda, which has sought to weaken democratic institutions and crack down on rising violence.
item.dc:creator: Emiliano Rodríguez Mega, David Bolaños and César Rodríguez
item.media:credit: Cesar Rodriguez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Laura Fernández at her closing campaign rally on Thursday night in San Antonio, Costa Rica.

item.title: How Trump Took Up the ‘Christian Genocide’ Cause in Nigeria
item.description: A yearslong effort to convince Washington of religious persecution is shifting foreign policy toward the West African nation, with major consequences.
item.dc:creator: Dionne Searcey, Zolan Kanno-Youngs, Ruth Maclean and Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Taibat Ajiboye for The New York Times
item.media:description: A resident of Jabo, Nigeria, with debris he said he found after a missile attack there on Dec. 25.

item.title: Why Is Taking the Rest of the Donetsk Region So Important to Putin?
item.description: Secretary of State Marco Rubio called the question “the one remaining item” in Abu Dhabi peace talks. Russia disputed that.
item.dc:creator: Paul Sonne
item.media:credit: Tyler Hicks/The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers in the Donetsk region of Ukraine, in December.

item.title: Years After Coup, Myanmar’s Government in Exile Teeters on Irrelevance
item.description: The National Unity Government was formed as a pro-democracy alternative to the junta. But, critics say, it has failed to achieve most of its goals.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak/The New York Times
item.media:description: Lining up to vote in the general election in Naypyidaw, Myanmar, in late December.

item.title: T. Kumar, Rights Activist Who Was Shaped by Time in Prison, Dies at 76
item.description: After being jailed as a resistance organizer for the Tamil minority in his native Sri Lanka, he spoke out against governmental repression worldwide.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nossiter
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
